Award.AwardTitle: Man-made Hazard Mitigation of Reservoir Dams: Monte Carlo Simulation with Multiscale Modeling of Concrete and Accurate Fluid-Structure Interaction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objective of this project is to study effective computational methods that will allow the failure and reliability analysis of dams subjected to man-made hazards, such as blast and penetration. This requires the accurate modeling of reservoir/dam failure response, which is not handled satisfactorily by available computational tools. The research approach progresses from the probabilistic modeling of concrete at the length scale of the major material heterogeneities to the formulation of a multi-scale framework for the analysis of large structures. The computational simulation of the dam is then coupled with the simulation of the reservoir water through a novel fluid-structure interaction algorithm. Finally, the developed framework is used to compute the probability of failure associated with projectile penetration and air-blasting.

The successful completion of this research will lead to a significant improvement in the computational tools for dam failure analysis available to practitioners. Engineers will be able to assess accurately the probability of failure of existing dams and dam administrators will be able to use these assessments to prioritize investments and resources. In addition, the research will have a significant impact on education and promotion of diversity through the wide range of activities aimed at the involvement of pre-college, undergraduate, and graduate students, especially those belonging to minority and underrepresented groups. This is achieved mainly by the development of an online NSF Virtual Center for Resilient Infrastructures (VCRI) in the context of the virtual reality world ?Second Life? (SL). The VCRI will give unprecedented opportunities for outreach activities, dissemination, and training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to formulate models for the simulation of concrete failure and fluid-structure interaction with the final objective of obtaining computational technologies to be used by engineers to estimate the response of critical infrastructures, such as reservoir dams, subject to man-made hazards. The two major outcomes of the project were a comprehensive model for concrete and an effective fluid-structure interaction model accounting for the precise simulation of the solid response.

 

The concrete model, entitled Lattice Discrete Particle Model (LDPM), simulates the internal structure of concrete at the level of coarse aggregate particles embedded in a mortar matrix. The particle interaction is formulated in such a way to have clear physical interpretation and to represent failure due to fracture, crushing and shearing. LDPM’s predictions were compared with experimental data both gathered from the literature and performed by the PI’s research group. The comparison with experimental data demonstrated LDPM’s unprecedented ability to simulated a large variety of failure phenomena at the macroscopic scale in both static and dynamic conditions. In particular, it numerical simulations showed the ability of LDPM to reproduce accurately failure mechanisms relevant to the effect of impacts and highly dynamic loading on concrete members.

 

The fluid-structure interaction framework, named “modified” immersed finite element method (mIFEM) adopts a non-boundary-fitted numerical technique to capture more precisely the solid dynamics by solving the solid governing equation instead of imposing it based on the fluid velocity field as in similar approaches available in the literature. In the mIFEM, the solid dynamics is solved using appropriate boundary conditions generated from the surrounding fluid, therefore produces more accurate and realistic coupled solutions. The work performed in this project demonstrates with several 2-D and 3-D testing cases that the mIFEM has a noticeable advantage in handling complicated fluid-structure interactions when the solid behavior dominates the fluid flow.

 

The research team disseminated the research results at various technical conferences and through peer-reviewed journal articles which were received very well but the relevant community of experts. Furthermore, the PI and co-PI performed outreach activities by visiting high school senior classrooms to discuss topics related to structural collapse and failure.
